0: not only frequently used,
1: but was of various sorts, as _cypre_, No. 41. 99. 120. named probably
2: from the isle of Cyprus, whence it might either come directly to us,
3: or where it had received some improvement by way of refining. There
4: is mention of _blanch-powder or white sugar_, 132. They, however,
5: were not the same, for see No. 193. Sugar was clarified sometimes
6: with wine [105].
7: 
8: Spices. _Species_. They are mentioned in general No. 133, and _whole
9: spices_, 167, 168. but they are more commonly specified, and are
10: indeed greatly used, though being imported from abroad, and from so
11: far as Italy or the Levant (and even there must be dear), some may
12: wonder at this: but it shouid be considered, that our Roll was
13: chiefly compiled for the use of noble and princely tables; and the
14: same may be said of the Editor's MS. The spices came from the same
15: part of the world, and by the same route, as sugar did. The _spicery_
16: was an ancient department at court, and had its proper officers.
17: 
18: As to the particular sorts, these are,
19: 
20: Cinamon. _Canell_. 14. 191. _Canel_, Editor's MS. 10. _Kanell_, ibid.
21: 32. is the Italian _Canella_. See Chaucer. We have the flour or
22: powder, No. 20. 62. See Wiclif. It is not once mentioned in Apicius.
23: 
24: Macys, 14. 121. Editor's MS. 10. _Maces_, 134. Editor's MS. 27. They
25: are used whole, No. 158. and are always expressed plurally, though we
26: now use the singular, _mace_. See Junii Etym.
27: 
28: Cloves. No. 20. Dishes are flourished with them, 22. 158. Editor's MS.
29: 10. 27. where we have _clowys gylofres_, as in our Roll, No. 104.
30: _Powdour gylofre_ occurs 65. 191. Chaucer has _clowe_ in the singular,
31: and see him v. Clove-gelofer.
32: 
33: Galyngal, 30. and elsewhere. Galangal, the long rooted cyperus [106],
34: is a warm cardiac and cephalic. It is used in powder, 30. 47. and was
35: the chief ingredient in _galentine_, which, I think, took its name
36: from it.
37: 
38: Pepper. It appears from Pliny that this pungent, warm seasoning, so
39: much in esteem at Rome [107], came from the East Indies [108], and,
40: as we may suppose, by way of Alexandria. We obtained it no doubt, in
41: the 14th century, from the same quarter, though not exactly by the
42: same route, but by Venice or Genoa. It is used both whole, No. 35,
43: and in powder, No. 83. And long-pepper occurs, if we read the place
44: rightly, in No. 191.
45: 
46: Ginger, gyngyn. 64. 136. alibi. Powder is used, 17. 20. alibi. and
47: Rabelais IV. c. 59. the white powder, 131. and it is the name of a
48: mess, 139. quære whether _gyngyn_ is not misread for _gyngyr_, for
49: see Junii Etym. The Romans had their ginger from Troglodytica [109].
50: 
51: Cubebs, 64. 121. are a warm spicy grain from the east.
52: 
53: Grains of Paradice, or _de parys_, 137. [110] are the greater
54: cardamoms.
55: 
56: Noix muscadez, 191. nutmegs.
57: 
58: The caraway is once mentioned, No. 53. and was an exotic from _Caria_,
59: whence, according to Mr. Lye, it took its name: 'sunt semina, inquit,
60: _carri_ vel _carrei_, sic dicti a Caria, ubi copiosissimè nascitur
61: [111].'
62: 
63: Powder-douce, which occurs so often, has been thought by some, who
64: have just peeped into our Roll, to be the same as sugar, and only a
65: different name for it; but they are plainly mistaken, as is evident
66: from 47. 51. 164. 165. where they are mentioned together as different
67: things. In short, I take powder-douce to be either powder of
68: galyngal, for see Editor's MS II. 20. 24, or a compound made of
69: sundry aromatic spices ground or beaten small, and kept always ready
70: at hand in some proper receptacle. It is otherwise termed _good
71: powders_, 83. 130. and in Editor's MS 17. 37. 38 [112]. or _powder_
72: simply, No. 169, 170. _White powder-douce_ occurs No. 51, which seems
73: to be the same as blanch-powder, 132. 193. called _blaynshe powder_,
74: and bought ready prepared, in Northumb. Book, p. 19. It is sometimes
75: used with powder-fort, 38. 156. for which see the next and last
76: article.
77: 
78: Powder-fort, 10. 11. seems to be a mixture likewise of the warmer
79: spices, pepper, ginger, &c. pulverized: hence we have _powder-fort of
80: gynger, other of canel_, 14. It is called _strong powder_, 22. and
81: perhaps may sometimes be intended by _good powders_. If you will

29: [Illustration: Take þe chese and of flessh of capouns, or of hennes
30: & hakke smal and grynde hem smale inn a morter, take mylke of
31: almandes with þe broth of freysh beef. oþer freysh flessh, & put the
32: flessh in þe mylke oþer in the broth and set hem to þe fyre, & alye
33: hem with flour of ryse, or gastbon, or amydoun as chargeaunt as þe
34: blank desire, & with zolks of ayren and safroun for to make hit zelow,
35: and when it is dressit in dysshes with blank desires; styk aboue
36: clowes de gilofre, & strawe powdour of galyugale above, and serue it
37: forth.]

0: tain contemporary writers, such as the Editor's MS,
1: of which we shall speak more particularly hereafter, Chaucer, and
2: Wiclif; with whom we have associated Junius' Etymologicon Anglicanum.
3: 
4: As the abbreviations of the Roll are here retained, in order to
5: establish and confirm the age of it, it has been thought proper to
6: adopt the types which our printer had projected for Domesday-Book,
7: with which we find that our characters very nearly coincide.
8: 
9: The names of the dishes and sauces have occasioned the greatest
10: perplexity. These are not only many in number, but are often so
11: horrid and barbarous, to our ears at least, as to be inveloped in
12: several instances in almost impenetrable obscurity. Bishop Godwin
13: complains of this so long ago as 1616 [115]. The _Contents_ prefixed
14: will exhibit at once a most formidable list of these hideous names
15: and titles, so that there is no need to report them here. A few of
16: these terms the Editor humbly hopes he has happily enucleated, but
17: still, notwithstanding all his labour and pains, the argument is in
18: itself so abstruse at this distance of time, the helps so few, and
19: his abilities in this line of knowledge and science so slender and
20: confined, that he fears he has left the far greater part of the task
21: for the more sagacious reader to supply: indeed, he has not the least
22: doubt, but other gentlemen of curiosity in such matters (and this
23: publication is intended for them alone) will be so happy as to clear
24: up several difficulties, which appear now to him insuperable. It must
25: be confessed again, thatthe Editor may probably have often failed in
26: those very points, which he fancies and flatters himself to have
27: elucidated, but this he is willing to leave to the candour of the
28: public.
29: 
30: Now in regard to the helps I mentioned; there is not much to be
31: learnt from the Great Inthronization-feast of archbishop Robert
32: Winchelsea, A. 1295, even if it were his; but I rather think it
33: belongs to archbishop William Warham, A. 1504 [116]. Some use,
34: however, has been made of it.
35: 
36: Ralph Bourne was installed abbot of St. Augustine's, near Canterbury,
37: A. 1309; and William Thorne has inserted a list of provisions bought
38: for the feast, with their prices, in his Chronicle [117].
39: 
40: The Great Feast at the Inthronization of George Nevile archbishop of
41: York, 6 Edward IV. is printed by Mr. Hearne [118], and has been of
42: good service.
43: 
44: Elizabeth, queen of king Henry VII. was crowned A. 1487, and the
45: messes at the dinner, in two courses, are registered in the late
46: edition of Leland's Collectenea, A. 1770 [119], and we have profited
47: thereby.
48: 
49: The Lenten Inthronization-feast of archbishop William Warham, A. 1504
50: [120], given us at large by Mr. Hearne [121], has been also consulted.
51: 
52: There is a large catalogue of viands in Rabelais, lib. iv. cap. 59.
53: 60. And the English translation of Mr. Ozell affording little
54: information, I had recourse to the French original, but not to much
55: more advantage.
56: 
57: There is also a Royal Feast at the wedding of the earl of Devonshire,
58: in the Harleian Misc. No. 279, and it has not been neglected.
59: 
60: Randle Holme, in his multifarious _Academy of Armory_, has an
61: alphabet of terms and dishes [122]; but though I have pressed him
62: into the service, he has not contributed much as to the more
63: difficult points.
64: 
65: The Antiquarian Repertory, vol. II. p. 211, exhibits an
66: entertainment of the mayor of Rochester, A. 1460; but there is little
67: to be learned from thence. The present work was printed before No. 31
68: of the Antiquarian Repertory, wherein some ancient recipes in Cookery
69: are published, came to the Editor's hand.
70: 
71: I must not omit my acknowledgments to my learned friend the present
72: dean of Carlisle, to whom I stand indebted for his useful notes on
73: the Northumberland-Household Book, as also for the book itself.
74: 
75: Our chief assistance, however, has been drawn from a MS belonging to
76: the Editor, denoted, when cited, by the signature _MS. Ed._ It is a
77: vellum miscellany in small quarto, and the part respecting this
78: subject consists of ninety-one English recipes (or _nyms_) in cookery.
79: These are disposed into two parts, and

75: FORME OF CURY.
76: 
77: ... fome [1] of cury [2] was compiled of the chef Maister Cokes of
78: kyng Richard the Secunde kyng of .nglond [3] aftir the Conquest. the
79: which was acounted þe [4] best and ryallest vyand [5] of alle
80: csten .ynges [6] and it was compiled by assent and avysement of
81: Maisters and [7] phisik [8] and of philosophie þat dwellid in his
82: court. First it techiþ a man for to make commune potages and commune
83: meetis for howshold as þey shold be made craftly and holsomly.
84: Aftirward it techiþ for to make curious potages & meetes and
85: sotiltees [9] for alle maner of States bothe hye and lowe. And the
86: techyng of the forme of making of potages & of meetes bothe of flessh
87: and of fissh. buth [10] y sette here by noumbre and by ordre. sso þis
88: little table here sewyng [11] wole teche a man with oute taryyng: to
89: fynde what meete þat hym lust for to have.

79: FOR TO MAKE GRONDEN BENES [1]. I.
80: 
81: Take benes and d

21: FOR TO MAKE GRONDEN BENES [1]. I.
22: 
23: Take benes and dry hem in a nost [2] or in an Ovene and hulle hem
24: wele and wyndewe [3] out þe hulk and wayshe hem clene an do hem to
25: seeþ in gode broth [4] an ete hem with Bacon.
26:

35: FOR TO MAKE DRAWEN BENES. II.
36: 
37: Take benes and seeþ hem and grynde hem in a morter [1] and drawe hem
38: up [2] with gode broth an do Oynouns in the broth grete mynced [3] an
39: do þerto and colour it with Safroun and serve it forth.
40:

46: FOR TO MAKE GREWEL FORCED [1]. III.
47: 
48: Take grewel and do to the fyre with gode flessh and seeþ it wel. take
49: the lire [2] of Pork and grynd it smal [3] and drawe the grewel
50: thurgh a Straynour [4] and colour it wiþ Safroun and serue [5] forth.
51:

59: CABOCHES [1] IN POTAGE. IIII.
60: 
61: 
62: Take Caboches and quarter hem and seeth hem in gode broth with
63: Oynouns y mynced and the whyte of Lekes y slyt and corue smale [2]
64: and do þer to safroun an salt and force it with powdour douce [3].
65:

71: RAPES [1] IN POTAGE. V.
72: 
73: Take rapus and make hem clene and waissh hem clene. quare hem [2].
74: parboile hem. take hem up. cast hem in a gode broth and seeþ hem.
75: mynce Oynouns and cast þerto Safroun and salt and messe it forth
76: with powdour douce. the wise [3] make of Pasturnakes [4] and
77: skyrwates. [5]
78:

88: EOWTES [1] OF FLESSH. VI.
89: 
90: Take Borage, cool [2]. langdebef [3]. persel [4]. betes. orage [5].
91: auance [6]. violet [7]. saueray [8]. and fenkel [9]. and whane þey
92: buth sode; presse hem wel smale. cast hem in gode broth an seeþ hem.
93: and serue hem forth.
94:

109: HEBOLACE [1]. VII.
110: 
111: 
112: Take Oynouns and erbes and hewe hem small and do þes to gode broth.
113: and aray [2] it as þou didest caboches. I

5: EOWTES [1] OF FLESSH. VI.
6: 
7: Take Borage, cool [2]. langdebef [3]. persel [4]. betes. orage [5].
8: auance [6]. violet [7]. saueray [8]. and fenkel [9]. and whane þey
9: buth sode; presse hem wel smale. cast hem in gode broth an seeþ hem.
10: and serue hem forth.
11: 
12: [1] Eowtes. _Lowtes_, No. 88, where, in the process, it is _Rowtes_.
13:     Quære the meaning, as Roots does not apply to the matter of the
14:     Recipe. In No. 73 it is written _owtes_.
15: [2] Cole, or colewort.
16: [3] Langdebef. Bugloss, buglossum sylvestre. These names all arise
17:     from a similitude to an ox's tongue. V. Ms. Ed. No. 43.
18: [4] Persel. Parsley.
19: [5] orage. Orach, _Atriplex_. Miller, Gard. Dict.
20: [6] auance. Fortè Avens. V. Avens, in Gloss.
21: [7] The leaves probably, and not the flower.
22: [8] Savory.
23: [9] Fenkel. Fennil.

26: HEBOLACE [1]. VII.
27: 
28: 
29: Take Oynouns and erbes and hewe hem small and do þes to gode broth.
30: and aray [2] it as þou didest caboches. If þey be in fyssh day. make
31: [3] on the same maner [4] with water and oyle. and if it be not in
32: Lent alye [5] it with zolkes of Eyren [6]. and dresse it forth and
33: cast þer to powdour douce.
34: 
35: [1] Hebolace. Contents, Hebolas; for _Herbolas_, from the herbs used;
36:     or, if the first letter be omitted (see the Contents), _Chebolas_,
37:     from the Chibols employed.
38: [2] aray. Dress, set it out.
39: [3] make. Dress. Vide Gloss.
40: [4] maner. manner.
41: [5] alye. Mix. V. Gloss.
42: [6] Eyren. Eggs. V. Gloss.

45: GOURDES IN POTAGE. VIII.
46: 
47: Take young Gowrdes pare hem and kerue [1] hem on pecys. cast hem in
48: gode broth, and do þer to a gode pertye [2] of Oynouns mynced. take
49: Pork soden. grynd it and alye it þer with and wiþ zolkes of ayrenn.
50: do þer to safroun and salt, and messe it forth with powdour douce.
51: 
52: [1] kerve. Cut.
53: [2] partye. Party, i.e. quantity.

56: RYSE [1] OF FLESH. IX.
57: 
58: Take Ryse and waishe hem clene. and do hem in erthen pot with gode
59: 
60: broth and lat hem seeþ wel. afterward take Almaund mylke [2] and do
61: þer to. and colour it wiþ safroun an salt, an messe forth.
62: 
63: [1] Ryse. Rice. V. Gloss.
64: [2] Almand mylke. V. Gloss.

67: FUNGES [1]. X.
68: 
69: Take Funges and pare hem clere and dyce hem [2]. take leke and shred
70: hym small and do hym to seeþ in gode broth. colour it with safron and
71: do þer inne powdour fort [3].
72: 
73: [1] Funges. Mushrooms.
74: [2] dyce hem. Cut them in squares. Vide _quare_ in Gloss.
75: [3] Powdour fort. Vide Preface.

78: BURSEN [1]. XI.
79: 
80: Take the whyte of Lekes. slype hem and shrede hem small. take
81: Noumbles [2] of swyne and boyle hem in broth and wyne. take hym up
82: and dresse hem and do the Leke in the broth. seeþ and do the Noumbles
83: þer to make a Lyour [3] of brode blode and vynegre and do þer to
84: Powdour fort seeþ Oynouns mynce hem and do þer to. the self wise make
85: of Pigges.
86: 
87: [1] Bursen. Qu. the etymon.
88: [2] Noumbles. Entrails. V. Gloss.
89: [3] Lyo', Lyour. A mixture. Vide _alye_ in Gloss.

92: CORAT [1]. XII.
93: 
94: Take the Noumbles of Calf. Swyne. or of Shepe. parboile hem and
95: skerne hem to dyce [2] cast hem in gode broth and do þer to erbes.
96: grynde chyballes [3]. smale y hewe. seeþ it tendre and lye it with
97: zolkes of eyrenn. do þer to verious [4] safroun powdour douce and
98: salt, and serue it forth.
99: 
100: [1] Corat. Qu.
101: [2] kerve hem to dyce. V. _quare_ in Gloss.
102: [3] Chyballes. Chibols, young onions. V. Gloss.
103: [4] verious. Verjuice.

106: NOUMBLES. XIII.
107: 
108: Take noumbles of Deer oþer [1] of oþer beest parboile hem kerf hem to
109: dyce. take the self broth or better. take brede and grynde with the
110: broth. and temper it [2] up with a gode quantite of vyneger and wyne.
111: take the oynouns and parboyle hem. and mynce hem smale and do þer to.
112: colour it with blode and do þer to powdour fort and salt and boyle it
113: wele and serue it fort [3].
114: 
115: [1] oþer. Other, i.e. or.
116: [2] temper it. Temper it, i. e. mix it.
117: [3] fort. Miswritten for _forth_. So again No. 31. 127.

120: ROO [1] BROTH. XIIII.
121: 
122: Take the lire of the Deer oþer of the Roo parboile it on smale peces.
123: seeþ it wel half in water and half in wyne. take brede and bray it
124: wiþ the self broth and drawe blode þer to and lat it seet

0: nde chyballes [3]. smale y hewe. seeþ it tendre and lye it with
1: zolkes of eyrenn. do þer to verious [4] safroun powdour douce and
2: salt, and serue it forth.

10: NOUMBLES. XIII.
11: 
12: Take noumbles of Deer oþer [1] of oþer beest parboile hem kerf hem to
13: dyce. take the self broth or better. take brede and grynde with the
14: broth. and temper it [2] up with a gode quantite of vyneger and wyne.
15: take the oynouns and parboyle hem. and mynce hem smale and do þer to.
16: colour it with blode and do þer to powdour fort and salt and boyle it
17: wele and serue it fort [3].

24: ROO [1] BROTH. XIIII.
25: 
26: Take the lire of the Deer oþer of the Roo parboile it on smale peces.
27: seeþ it wel half in water and half in wyne. take brede and bray it
28: wiþ the self broth and drawe blode þer to and lat it seeth to gedre
29: with powdour fort of gynger oþer of canell [2]. and macys [3]. with a
30: grete porcioun of vineger with Raysouns of Coraunte [4].

38: TREDURE [1]. XV.
39: 
40: Take Brede and grate it. make a lyre [2] of rawe ayrenn and do þerto
41: Safroun and powdour douce. and lye it up [3] with gode broth. and
42: make it as a Cawdel. and do þerto a lytel verious.

50: MONCHELET [1]. XVI.
51: 
52: Take Veel oþer Moton and smite it to gobettes seeþ it in gode broth.
53: cast þerto erbes yhewe [2] gode wyne. and a quantite of Oynouns
54: mynced. Powdour fort and Safroun. and alye it with ayren and verious.
55: but lat not seeþ after.

61: BUKKENADE [1]. XVII.
62: 
63: Take Hennes [2] oþer Conynges [3] oþer Veel oþer oþer Flessh an hewe
64: hem to gobettes waische it and hit well [4]. grynde Almandes
65: unblaunched. and drawe hem up with þe broth cast þer inne raysons of
66: Corance. sugur. Powdour gyngur erbes ystewed in grees [5]. Oynouns
67: and Salt. If it is to to [6] thynne. alye it up with flour of ryse
68: oþer with oþer thyng and colour it with Safroun.

81: CONNATES [1]. XVIII.
82: 
83: Take Connes and pare hem. pyke out the best and do hem in a pot of
84: erthe. do þerto whyte grece þat he stewe þer inne. and lye hem up
85: with hony clarified and with rawe zolkes [2] and with a lytell
86: almaund mylke and do þerinne powdour fort and Safron. and loke þat it
87: be yleesshed [3],

95: DREPEE [1]. XIX.
96: 
97: Take blanched Almandes grynde hem and temper hem up with gode broth
98: take Oynouns a grete quantite parboyle hem and frye hem and do þerto.
99: take smale bryddes [2] parboyle hem and do þerto Pellydore [3] and
100: salt. and a lytel grece.

107: Mawmenee [1]. XX.
108: 
109: Take a pottel of wyne greke. and ii. pounde of sugur take and
110: clarifye the sugur with a qantite of wyne an drawe it thurgh a
111: straynour in to a pot of erthe take flour of Canell [2]. and medle [3]
112: with sum of the wyne an cast to gydre. take pynes [4] with Dates and
113: frye hem a litell in grece oþer in oyle and cast hem to gydre. take
114: clowes [5] an flour of canel hool [6] and cast þerto. take powdour
115: gyngur. cane

0:  loke þat it
1: be yleesshed [3],
2: 
3: [1] Connat seems to be a kind of marmalade of connes, or quinces,
4:     from Fr. _Coing_. Chaucer, v. Coines. Written quinces No. 30.
5: [2] Yolkes, i. e. of Eggs.
6: [3] yleesshed. V. Gloss.
7: 
8:

9: DREPEE [1]. XIX.
10: 
11: Take blanched Almandes grynde hem and temper hem up with gode broth
12: take Oynouns a grete quantite parboyle hem and frye hem and do þerto.
13: take smale bryddes [2] parboyle hem and do þerto Pellydore [3] and
14: salt. and a lytel grece.
15: 
16: [1] Drepee. Qu.
17: [2] bryddes. Birds. _Per metathesin; v. R. in Indice_.
18: [3] Pellydore. Perhaps _pellitory_. _Peletour_, 104.
19: 
20: 
21: Mawmenee [1]. XX.

22: 
23: Take a pottel of wyne greke. and ii. pounde of sugur take and
24: clarifye the sugur with a qantite of wyne an drawe it thurgh a
25: straynour in to a pot of erthe take flour of Canell [2]. and medle [3]
26: with sum of the wyne an cast to gydre. take pynes [4] with Dates and
27: frye hem a litell in grece oþer in oyle and cast hem to gydre. take
28: clowes [5] an flour of canel hool [6] and cast þerto. take powdour
29: gyngur. canel. clower, colour it with saundres a lytel yf hit be nede
30: cast salt þerto. and lat it seeþ; warly [7] with a slowe fyre and not
31: to thyk [8], take brawn [9] of Capouns yteysed [10]. oþer of
32: Fesauntes teysed small and cast þerto.
33: 
34: [1] Vide No. 194, where it is called _Mawmenny_.
35: [2] Flour of Canell. Powder of Cinamon.
36: [3] medle. Mix.
37: [4] pynes. A nut, or fruit. Vide Gloss.
38: [5] clowes. Cloves.
39: [6] hool. Whole. How can it be the flour, or powder, if whole? Quære,
40:     _flower_ of cand for _mace_.
41: [7] warly. Warily, gently.
42: [8] not to thyk. So as to be too thick; or perhaps, _not to thicken_.
43: [9] brawn. Fleshy part. Few Capons are cut now except about Darking
44:     in Surry; they have been excluded by the turkey, a more magnificent,
45:     but perhaps not a better fowl.
46:

47: [10] yteysed, or _teysed_, as afterwards. Pulled in pieces by the
48:      fingers, called _teezing_ No. 36. This is done now with flesh of
49:      turkeys, and thought better than mincing. Vide Junius, voce _Tease_.
50: 
51: 
52: EGURDOUCE [1]. XXI.
53: 
54: Take Conynges or Kydde and smyte hem on pecys rawe. and frye hem in
55: white grece. take raysouns of Coraunce and fry hem take oynouns
56: parboile hem and hewe hem small and fry hem. take rede wyne suger
57: with powdour of peper. of gynger of canel. salt. and cast þerto. and
58: lat it seeþ with a gode quantite of white grece an serue it forth.
59: 
60: [1] Egurdouce. The term expresses _piccante dolce_, a mixture of sour
61:     and sweet; but there is nothing of the former in the composition.
62:     Vide Gloss.
63: 
64: 
65: CAPOUNS IN COUNCYS [1]. XXII.

66: 
67: Take Capons and rost hem right hoot þat þey be not half y nouhz and
68: hewe hem to gobettes and cast hem in a pot, do þerto clene broth,
69: seeþ hem þat þey be tendre. take brede and þe self broth and drawe it
70: up yferer [2], take strong Powdour and Safroun and Salt and cast þer
71: to. take ayrenn and seeþ hem harde. take out the zolkes and hewe the
72: whyte þerinne, take the Pot fro þe fyre and cast the whyte þerinne.
73: messe the disshes þerwith and lay the zolkes hool and flour it with
74: clowes.
75: 
76: [1] Concys seems to be a kind of known sauce. V. Gloss.
77: [2] yfere. Together.
78: 
79: 
80: HARES [1] IN TALBOTES [2]. XXIII.

81: 
82: Take Hares and hewe hem to gobettes and seeþ hem with þe blode
83: unwaisshed in broth. and whan þey buth y nowh: cast hem in colde
84: water. pyke and waisshe hem clene. cole [3] the broth and drawe it
85: thurgh a straynour. take oþer blode and cast in boylyng water seeþ it
86: and drawe it thurgh a straynour. take Almaundes unblaunched. waisshe
87: hem and grynde hem and temper it up with the self broth. cast al in a
88: pot. tak oynouns and parboile hem smyte hem small and cast hem in to
89: þis Pot. cast þerinne Powdour fort. vynegur an salt.
90: 
91: [1] Haares, Contents. So again, No. 24.
92: [2] Talbotes. Ms. Ed. No. 9, _Talbotays_.
93: [3] Cole. Cool.
94: 
95: 
96: HARES IN PAPDELE [1]. XXIIII.

97: 
98: Take Hares parboile hem in gode broth. cole the broth and waisshe the
99: fleyssh. cast azeyn [2] to gydre. take obleys [3] oþer wafrouns [4]
100: in stede of lozeyns [5]. and cowche [6] in dysshes. take powdour
101: douce and lay on salt the broth and lay onoward [7] an messe forth.
102: 
103: [1] Papdele.
